monogr.title: John Lydgate's Dance of Death and Related Works

projectDesc.p: The Middle English Texts Series offers a diverse and representative array of literary texts that medieval readers in the present-day British Isles would have encountered between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries. It is committed to making available both affordable print and open access editions to scholars, teachers, and students of the Western Middle Ages. In its digital publications, the series prioritizes a user-friendly interface and viewing options, multiple downloadable formats, enhanced searchability and filtering, and accessibility to the widest possible range of users.

editorialDecl.p: METS takes as its mission the creation of affordable editions that would pass scrutiny from the most demanding expert, yet would prove comprehensible, and even enticing, to someone who had never read Middle English before. This agenda dictates that METS publications offer not a critical edition reflecting all surviving manuscripts, and certainly not a diplomatic edition, but a best-text edition, informed by the notes and apparatus of earlier editions (where these exist), and by substantive variants from other manuscript witnesses. Transcriptions of Middle English texts are lightly modernized to ensure a smooth reading experience, while non-English texts preserve both the original language and a modern English translation in facing-page format. Each edition offers expert assistance with language and lexicon, providing glosses alongside the text(s), textual and explanatory notes, elucidation of unfamiliar contexts and traditions, and thematic and interpretive possibilities. All editions feature general introductions that set the edited text within its own time, place, and traditions, and link it to ancestor, congener, and successor materials. All publications contain comprehensive, current bibliographies of pertinent scholarship and criticism. House style is adapted from the Chicago Manual of Style.

correction.p: This text may include corrections made after the original edition went to press in order to correct errors and improve glosses. For a full list of editorial and typographical corrections made to this edition, please view its correction log on Github: https://github.com/mets-editions/cook-lydgate/blob/main/cook-lydgate-export-corrections-log.docx

lg.l: fol. 41vO creatures yeT that been resonable,Ghave reason
The liff desiryng which is eternall,
Ye may seenG heer doctrine ful notable,see
Your liffG to leede which that is mortall,life
Therby to lerne in especiallGin particular
How ye shal traceG the daunce which that ye seefollow
To man and wooman ylicheG naturall,T alike
For Deth ne sparithG hih nor lowe degre.does not spare
In this myrrourN every man may fynde
That hym behovyth to goonG upon this daunce.That he must go
Whoo gothG before or who goth behynde,goes
All dependith in Goddis ordynaunce.GGod’s plan
Wherfore eche mann lowlyG take his chaunce;humbly
Deth spareth nothir poore nor blood roiall.Groyal
Eche man therfore have this in remembraunce:
Of oon mateer God hath forgid all.1
Ye that be sett hih in dignyté
Of all estatis in erthe spirituall,GOut of all religious positions on earth
And lik to Petir have the sovereyntéN
Ovir the chirche most in especiall:Gin particular
Upon this daunce ye first begynne shall,
As most worthi lord and governour,
For al the worshippeG of your estat papallGhigh esteem papal estate
And of all lordshippeG to God is the honour.dominion
First me bihovythG this daunce with Deth to leede,It is proper for me
WichG sat in erthe hihest in my seeG —Who seat of authority
Thestat ful perilousT whoso takith heede
To occupie Seynt Petris dignyté —2
But for al that froG Deth I may nat flee,from
Upon this daunce with othirG for to trace,Gwith others to follow
For sichG honour, who prudently can see,such
Is litel worthe that doth so soone passe.Gpass [away]
Sir Emperour, lord of all the ground,Gearth
Most sovereynG prynce surmountyng of noblesse:Gpreeminent nobility
Ye must forsake of gold your appill round,N
SeptreG and swerdG and all your hih prowesse.GScepter sword martial deeds
Behynde yow latG tresour and richesse,leave
And with othir to my daunce obeye.
AgeynG my mythT G vailethG non hardynesse;GAgainst might prevails valor
Adamis childrenG all thei must deye.Adam’s children (i.e., humanity)
I notG to whom I may appele,Gknow not appeal
Whan Deth me sailithG that doth me constreyn.Gassails compel
Ther is no gynneG to socourG my quarele,Gaid assist complaint
But spade and picoisG my grave to atteyne,Gpickaxe reach
A symple shete — ther is no more to seyn —N Gto say
To wrappen in my body and visage,T Gface
Wherupon soreG I me compleynfervently
That lordis grete have litel avauntage.Gadvantage
Ye be abaissht,G it seemeth, and in drede,Gupset full of dread
Sir Cardynall — it seemeth bi your cheerG —expression
But for al that ye folwe shalG in deedeGyou shall follow indeed
With othir estates this daunce for to leer.T Gto learn
Your gret arrayG al shal levynG heer,fine clothing shall be left
Your hatt of red,N your vestureG of gret cost.garment
Al these thynges rekenyd weel ifeere:3
In gret worship good avysT G is lost.judgment
I have gret cause — trewlyG it is no faileG —certainly mistake
To been abaisshtG and gretelyT to dreedeG me,upset to have great dread
SithG Deth is come me sodeynly tassaile,GBecause to attack me suddenly
That I shallT nevir hereaftirT clothid be
In griseG nor ermynG lik to my degré;gray fur (possibly squirrel) ermine
Myn hat ofT red levynG heer in distresse,leave
Bi whichT I have lernyd weel and see
How that al joie eendith in hevynesse.Gsorrow
Lat seG your hand, my lady dame Empresse,Let [me] see
Have no disdeynG with me for to daunce.scorn
Ye may aside leynG al your richesse,leave aside
Your fresh attyres,G devises of plesaunce,Gfancy clothes stratagems of flattery
Your soleyn cheeris,G your strange countenaunce,Gdistant expression haughty attitude
Your clothis of gold most uncouthly wrouht,Goutlandishly made
Havyng of Deth ful litel remembrance.
But now yeT se weel al is come to nouht.Gnothing
What availethG gold, richesse,G orT perre,GWhat use is wealth precious stones
Or what availeth hih blood or jentylnesse,Ghigh birth or nobility
Or what availeth freshnesseG or beauté,radiance
Or what is worth hih porteG orT straungenesse?T Ghaughty attitudealoofness
Deth seith chekmatN G to al sich veynG noblesse.checkmate vain
All worldly power now may me nat availe:
Raunsoun,G kynrede,G frenshippe,G nor worthynesse,Ransom kindred friendship
SynG Deth is come myn hih estate tassaile.GBecause to attack
Sir Patriarch, ful sad and humble of cheere,N Gattitude
Ye moteG with othir gon on this daunce with me.T must
Your dowble crosN G of gold and stonys cleer,double cross
Your power hool,G and al your dygnytéGwhole rank
Som othir shal of trouth and equitéGtruth and fairness
Be possessidT in hast, as I rehers can.Gas I can say
Trust nevyr that ye shal pope be,
For folyG hope disseiveth many a man.foolish
Worldly honour, grete tresour,T and richesse
HaveT me disseyvedG sothfastly in deede.Gdeceived truly indeed
My joies old be turned to distresse.
What availeth itT G sichG honour to possede?GWhat use is it suchpossess
Hih clymbyng up a fal hath to his meede;Gfor its reward
Gret estat folk waste out of noumbre.4
Whoso mountith hihest stondith most in drede,5
Such hevy berden doth hem ofteT encoumbre.
Right noble kyng, most worthi of renoun,Grenown
CumG forth anonG for al your worthynesse,GCome at once nobility
That somtyme had so gret possession,Gpossession of lands
RewmysG obeyng unto your hih noblesse.GRealms high nobility
Ye mostG of natureG to this daunce yow dresseGmust naturally prepare yourself
And fynally your crowne and sceptre leete.Gleave
For whoso most haboundithG in gret rychesseabounds
Shal bere with hym but a sengle sheete.Gsingle [winding] sheet
I have nat lernyd heer afforn toG daunceheretofore
No daunce in sothG of fotyng so savage,Gin truth frenzied
Wherbi I see ful cleerly in substaunce:Gin essence
What pride is worth force or hih parage?6
Deth all fordothG — this is his usageG —destroys practice
Gret and smal that in this world sojourne.
Who that is most meek hath most avauntage,
For we shul all to dede asshis torne.
Sir Archebisshop, whiT do ye so withdraweGretreat
Your look, your face as it wer bi disdeyn?Gwith contempt
Yee must obey to myT mortal lawe:
It to constreyneG it were but in veyn.to control
For day bi day, be right wele certeyn,
Deth at hond pursewith every coste.Gcourse of action
PreestesG and Deth may nat be holden ageyn,GLoans delayed
For at oonG our men contithG wit ther oste.Gthe [last] hour reckon host
Allas, I wot nat what partye for to flee,Gdon’t know where to flee
For dreede of Deth I stonde in sichG distresse,such
Tescape his power I can no refute see.7
But who thatT knewe his constreyntG and duresse,Goppression cruelty
He wolde take reson to maistresseGmistress
And seyn adieuT G pompe, and pride also,say goodbye
My peynted paleys,G my tresour,T and richesse.painted palace
Thyng that behovyth nedis must be do.8
Riht myhty prynce, be rith weell certeynGbe completely certain
ThisT daunce to yow is not eschewable.T Gnot avoidable
For more myhty than ever was Carlemayn,N GCharlemagne
Or worthy Arthour of prowesG ful notablemilitary deeds
With al his knyhtes ofT the Rounde Table —N
What did ther platis,G ther armour, or ther maile,Gplate armor chainmail
Ther strong corage,G ther sheeldes defensable,Gspirit defensive shields
Ageyns Deth availeT whan he hemG dide assaile?them
My purpos was and myn entencionGintent
To assegeT G castellisG and myhtiG forteresses,T besiege castles mighty
Rebellis to bryng unto subjeccion,
To seeke worship,T fame, and grete rychesses.T
But I se weel that al wordly prowessesT Gearthly valor
Deth can abate,G wherof I have despite.Gdemolish contempt
To hym allonG sorwe ekeG swetnesses,T alone also
For ageynsG Deth is founde no respite.Gagainst reprieve
Com ner, Sir Bisshoppe, with your myteer and croos,Gmiter and cross
For al your richesse, soth I yow ensure,Gtruly I assure you
For al your tresour so longe kepte in cloos,Gprivately owned
Your wordly goodisG and goodis of nature,Gearthly goods natural goods (e.g., crops)
And of your sheep the gostly dreedful cure,Gspiritual serious duty
With charge commytted to your prelacie,Gprelacy (office of the bishop)
For to acounteT ye shal be brouht to lure.N Gbrought under control
No wihtG is sewrG that clymbith on hih.person secure
Of these tidynges I am nothyngG glaad,not at all
Which Deth to me so sodeynlyG doth bryng.suddenly
It makith my face and countenaunce ful saad
That for discomfort me lystG nothyng to syng;desire
The worldT contrary to me in werkyng
Which al estatis can so disherite.Gdisinherit
And needis we must onto our departyng,
And al shal passe save oonly our merite.9

div.p: fol. 44r¶ Comes et BaroN GEarl and Baron

lg.l: Erl or Baron, which that thourhT G regiounsthrough
Have soreG laboured for worship and renoun,earnestly
Forget your trompetis and your clariouns.
ThisT is no dreem nor symulacioun.Gdeception
Somtyme your custom and your entencounGdesire
Was in estat and wordly wurshippe to glade,Gto take joy
But often tyme it happith, in conclusion,
OoG man brekythG that anothir made.One breaks
Ful often tyme I have ben auttorisedGauthorized
To hih empryseG and thyng of gret fame.martial deeds
Of gret estatis my thankG also devised,Ggratitude contrived
CherishidT with princes and lordis hih of name,
Nor nevyr on me was put no diffame10
In roial courtes, which that weer notable.
But Deth unwarlyG al power makith lame,Gunexpectedly helpless
And undir hevene in erthe is nothyng stable.

div.p: ¶ Abbas et priorN GAbbot and prior

lg.l: Sir Abbot and Priour with your broodG hatt,broad
To been abasshtG ye have a maner riht.Gupset good reason
Gret is your hed, your belyG rounde and fatt;belly
Ye must come daunce thouh ye be nat liht.
LevenG your lordshippe to som othir wiht,GLeave person
Your eyerG is of age your stateT G to ocupye.heir position
Whoso is fattest to hym I have behiht,Ghim I have designated
In his grave sonnestG shal putrefie.Gsoonest decay
Of thy manaceG I have no gret envyeGthreat grudge
That I shal leve al maner governaunce.
But that I shal as a cloistrerG die —cloistered monk
This doth to me somwhat the lesse grevaunce.N Gsomewhat lesser offence
My libertes nor my gret aboundaunce,11
What may thei availeG in any maner wise?Ghelp any kind of way
Yit aske I mercy with devoute repentaunce,
Thouh toforn Deth too late men them avise.Gexamine themselves
And ye, my lady gentylG dame Abbesse,of noble rank or birth
With your mantylG furryd large and wide,sleeveless overgarment
Your veile, your wympil,G your ryng of gret richesse,headdress
And beddisG softe ye must now leyne aside,Gbedding discard
For to this daunce I must be your gyde.
Thouh ye be tendre,G born of gentilG blood,delicate noble
Whil that ye live yoursilf provide,Gprepare yourself
For aftir Deth no man hath no good.T Gpossessions
Allas, that Deth hath for me soT ordeyned
That in no wiseG I may nat hym eschewe;Gway escape
Unto this daunceT of rihtG I am constreynedGrightly compelled
That heer with othir I must his trace sewe.Gfollow his steps
This pilgrymage to every man is dewe,Gdue
An ernest mateer,G a mateer of no jape.Gmatter joke
Who that is alwey redy shal nevir reweGregret
The hour abydyngG that God hath for hym shape.Gawaiting created
That hand of youres, my Lord Justice,
That have rewlidG so long the lawe,ruled
WeelG may men holde yow warG and wise,Well knowledgeable
So that this drauht be weel drawe;Gdrawn
Escape shal ye nat, wold ye never so fawe,Gdesirous
Sich dome to have as ye have yoven in soth.12
Wherfore men seyn of an old sawe:Gadage
Weel is hym that alwey weelG doth.N well
Allas, ne were that myn entent
Was weele dressid,G thouh I othirwhileG erryd.intended well otherwise
Now shuld I uttrely be shamyd and shentGharmed
For many causes that I have oftyn deferrid,T Greferred to a higher court
Sauff mercy oonly now were I marrid.13
BlissidG therfore is every wiht,GBlessed person
As bi Holy Scriptur may ben averrid,Gdemonstrated
That in all tyme doth lawe and kepith riht.

div.p: fol. 45r¶ Doctor utrisque IurisGDoctor of both laws

lg.l: Com forth, Doctour of Canon and Cyvile.N
In bothe these lawis of long contynuaunce,
Your tyme hath spent — bewar ye did no gileG —deceit
In your mateersG for to han fortheraunce.Gmatters personal benefit
Now must ye lerne with me for to daunce;
All your lawe may yow nat availe.Gassist
Giff me your hand and make no perturbaunce:
Your hour is come — this is withouten faile.
A mercy, Jhesu, whow mankynde is freeleGfrail
And litel tyme in this worlde abydyng;
No man of his liffG hath charter nor seele.N Glifeseal
Therfore it may be likned in all thyng
Unto a flour so amorously floorsshyng,Gardently flourishing
Which with a froste bigynneth riht soneG to fade.immediately
Whan cruell Deth his massageG listG to bryng,message chooses
Al lifflyG thyng he bryngeth in the shade.T living

div.p: ¶ Miles et armigerN GKnight or squire

lg.l: Knyht or Scwyer, riht fressh of your arayGattire
That canG of daunsesG al the newe gise:T Gknows dances fashion
Thouh ye bare armes wele-horsid yisterday,14
With speere and sheeld at your uncouth devise,T Gof outlandish design
And took upon yow many strange emprise,T Gremarkable deeds
Dansith with us, it wole no bettir be;
Ther is no socour in no maner wise,Gassistance of any kind
For no man may from Dethis power flee.
SithT G that Deth meT holdith in his lace,GBecause snare
YitG shal I speke a woord orG I pace:GYet before go
Adieu, al myrthe, adieu now al solace;
Adieu, my ladies somtyme so fresshG of face;youthful
Adieu, beauté that lastith but short space!Gtime
Of Dethis chaunge every day is pryme;Ga new beginning
Thynk on your sowlis or that Deth manace,Gbefore Death threatens
For al shal rote,G and no mann wotG what tyme.decay knows
Com forth, Sir Mayr, which had governaunce
Bi pollicieG to rewleG this cité:policy rule
Thouh your power were notableG in substaunce,great
To flee my daunce ye have no liberté.Gfreedom
Estate is noon nor wordly dygnyté15
That may escape onT G of my daungeris.Gany powers
To fynde rescew exaumple ye may se
Nouthir bi richesse nor force of officeres.16
What helpith now thestatG in which I stood,the estate
To rewleG cites or comounsG to governe,rule populaces
Plente of richesse, or increceG of good,increase
Or olde wynnyngG that cometh to me so yerne?Gwealth quickly
Deth al defaceth, whoso listG to lerne;desires
Me for taresteG he comyth on so faste.to arrest
Eche man therfore shold aforeG discernein advance
Prudently to thynk upon his laste.
Lat see your hand, Sir Chanon Reguler,N
Somtyme yswornT G to religion,vowed
As humble sogetG and obedienceer,Gsubject subordinate
Chastly to live likG your profession.according to
But ther may be no consolacion
Ageyn my sawesG sodeyn and cruell,decrees
Except oonly — for short conclusion —
Who liveth in vertu motG nedis dey weel.virtuously must
Whi shulde I grutcheG or disobeyecomplain
The thyng toT which, of verreyT kyndly riht,Gby truly natural right
Was I ordeyned and born for to deye,
As in this world is ordeyned every wiht?Gperson
Which to remembre is nothyng liht;Gno small thing
PrayngG the Lord that was spradG on the RoodeGPraying spreadCross
To medleG mercy with His eternal myhtGmix power
And save the sowles that he bouht with his blood.
Sir Dean or Chanon, with many gret prebend,N
Ye may no lenger haG distribuciounsGhave a share [of alms]
In gret arrayG your tresour to dispende,Gfine clothing to squander
With all your richesse and your possessiouns,
For KyndeG hath sett hir revoluciouns,Nature
Eche man som day to daunce on Dethis brynk.
Therof ye may have no dilaciouns,Gdelays
For Deth cometh evirG whan men lestG on hym thynke.always least
My divers cures, my riche personages —N
Allas ful litelG thei may me now comforte.very little
Deth upon me hath geten his avantages;Ggot the better of me
All my richesse can make me now no sporte.Gno consolation
AmysT of grey,G thei must ageyn resorteGFine garments of grey return
Unto the world with many a gret prebende;
For which trewly, as clerkis can reporte,
To deye weel eche man sholde entende.
Thouh ye be barbidG and claadG in clothis blaake,N tonsured wearing
Chastly receyved the mantilG and the ryng,N Gmantle ring
Ye may nat the cours of nature forsake,
To daunce with othir now at my comyng.
In this world is non abidyng,Gno one living
NouthirG of maide, widewe, nor wiff,Neither
As ye may seen heer cleerly bi wrytyng,
That ageyns Deth is founde no preservatiff.Gprotection
It helpith nat to stryve ageyn Nature,
Namely whan Deth bigynneth tassaile,Gbegins to attack
Wherfore I counseil every creature
To been redy ageyn this fel batayle.Gfierce battle
VertuG is sewrerG than othir plateG or maile,GVirtue more secure either armor chainmail
Also nothyng may helpe more atT sich a nede
Than to provide a sur acquytaile
With the hand of almesseG to love God and drede.17alms
YeveG me your hand with chekis ded and pale,Give
Causid of watcheG and long abstynence,wakefulness (i.e., for a vigil)
Sir Chartreux,N and dothT your chyne valeGlower your chin
Unto this daunce with humble pacience.
To stryve ageynG may be no resistence;against
Lenger to live set nat your memorie.Gdirect not your attention
Thouh I be lothsomG outward in apparence,loathsome
Above all men Deth hath the victorie.
Unto this world I was dedT ago ful longe
Bi myn ordreG and my profession.[Carthusian] order
Thowgh everyT man, be he nevyr so strong,
DredithT to deye bi naturall mocionGnatural instinct
Afftyr his flesshly inclynacion,
Plese it the LordT my sowle for to borweGborrow
Fro feendis myhtG and fro dampnacion;Gthe Devil’s might damnation
Som arnG today that shal nat be tomorwe.are
Come neer, Sir Sergeant,N short processeG for to make,legal argument
Ye must cum pleete aforeG the JugeT on hihe,plead your case before
Many a quarellG thouh ye have undirtakecomplaint
And for lucreG doon folk gret remedie.Gprofit legal redress
Ther shal your sotilG wittis be deemyd foly,T crafty
Yif sleatheG and covetiseG be nat exiled.sloth covetousness
Bewar bitymesG and labour for mercy,promptly
For thei that trust most themsilfG ar sonnest bigiled.Gthemselves deceived
Of riht and reson bi Natures lawe,T
I can alleggenG nor make no diffence,Gmake a formal legal claim defense
Nor bi sleihteG nor statute me withdraweGcunning myself excuse
TescapeG awey from this dreedful sentence,To escape
For al my witt nor gret prudence.N
No thyng inT erthe may no man preserve
Ageyns His myht to make resistence;
God qwytethG al men lyke as they deserve.T repays
Com forth maistresse,G of yeeres yong and greneGmistress fresh
Which hold yoursilff of beauté sovereyn.Gpreeminent
As fair as ye wasT whilomG Polliceene,N T Gonce Polyxena
PenolopeT andT the queen Eleyn,N GHelen
YitG on this daunce thei wentT bothe tweyn,N GYet both of them
And so shal ye forG al your strangenesse.Gdespite haughtiness
Thouh deynous daungeerG longe hath lad your reyn,Gscornful resistance reign
Unto this daunce ye moteG your fotyngG dresse.Gmust footing turn
O cruel Deth that sparist non estat,
To old and yong thou art indifferent.
To my beauté thou hast seyd chekmat,Gcheckmate
So hastyG is thi mortall jugement.swift
For in my youthe this was myn entent,
To my servise many a man to have lurid.Glured
But she is a fool, shortlyG in sentement,concisely
That in hir beauté is too myche assurid.
Com forth, mayster,T that loken up so ferre
With instrumentis of astronomye
To take the grees and hitheG of every sterre.degrees and height
What may availeG al your astrologye,T help
SithG of Adam al the genealogie,GSince descendants
Maade first of God to walke upon theT gronde,
Deth doth arrest? Thus seith theologie,
And alle shul deie for an appyll rounde.N
For al my craft, connyng, or scienceGknowledge
I can fynde no provision,Gprovision (i.e., against death)
Nor in the sterrisT serche out no difference,
Bi domofyengG norT calculacion,By locating the position of the stars
SauffG fynaly — in conclusion —Except
For to descriveT G our connyng every deel,Gexplain in every aspect
Ther is no more bi sentenceG of reson,by doctrine
Who livith aryghtT most nedis deye weel.Gmust necessarily die well
Com forth, thou frere, to thee myn hand is rauhtGextended
Upon this daunce thee to conveie and lede,
Which in thi prechyngT hast ful ofteT tauht,Gtaught
How that I am gastfullG for to dreedeterrifying
(Althouh that folk take ther of non heede).
Yit is ther nonG so strong nor so hardy,Gno one fearless
But I dar arrestG hym and lettG for no meede,Gconfinefree compensation
For Deth eche hour is present and redy.
What may this be that in this world no man
Heer for tabideG may have no sureté?Gto abide certainty
Strengthe, richesse,T nor what so thatT he can:Gnor anything else he can do
OfT wordly wisdam is al but vanité.Gvanity
In gret estate nor in poverté
Is no thyng founde that may fro Deth deffende,
For which I sei to hih and lowe degré,

note.gloss: God has made everyone from the same matter
Lines 27–28: The very dangerous position, whoso takes heed / To occupy St. Peter’s rank
Each and every one of these valuable things adjudicated together
Folk waste more great estates than can be numbered
Whoever rises highest stands most in dread
What kind of power or high birth is worth taking pride in?
I see no refuge in which to escape his power
The thing that is proper to do must be done
Everything will pass away except our good deeds
No slander was ever put on me
My legal privileges nor my great wealth
Such judgment to have as you have given in truth
Except for mercy, I would now be destroyed
Though you bore arms well on horseback yesterday
There is no status or worldly rank
Lines 263–64: You cannot find examples in which someone escaped / Because of their riches or the power of their office
Lines 318–20: Nothing does more to help / And provide an acquittal in such a difficult situation / Than demonstrating one’s love and dread of God through the giving of alms
